texts.definition: Groups of characters working together to reach common diegetic goals.
markups: <style="Definition">Groups of characters working together to reach common diegetic goals.</style>

Cooperating usually makes it easier to succeed with tasks. For this reason, games where players have characters may places these in <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> with other characters so that they together can try to reach the goals provided by games. The other characters may be controlled by other players - requiring

<style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> first emerged in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basic%20Role-Playing">Basic Role-Playing</link></style> system. While <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> simply represented the characters of the players currently  playing the structure of the games made it advantageous that characters' had diverse skill sets, e.g. complementing combat-oriented characters with those that could heal or find social solutions to problems. The third edition of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> introduced game mechanics specifically oriented to <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>: the players have to collectively choose which type of party they are with the associated advantages and disadvantages this has. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> provides some possibilities for players to get party-specific advantages (e.g. the "Teamwork" perk).

Like most other features, <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> continued to be used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20series">Ultima series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Baldur's%20Gate%20series">Baldur's Gate series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>. In these single-player games, the players create <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> with non-player characters and may have to choose between which ones to have in the group. In contrast, players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> need to organize themselves in "raid" groups of appropriate sizes to complete the "instances" provided by the game. In this game concepts such as "tank", "healer", "crowd controller", and "damage dealer" have flourished as players have developed combat strategies. These have in turn influenced the fourth edition of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, which uses functional descriptions such as "leader", "controller", "striker", and "defender".

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/UFO%20series">UFO series</link></style> shows examples of small scale strategy games where players create <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> to go into battles against extraterrestrial enemies. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> is built around four characters completing the games' levels; the computer takes the roles of characters if there are less than four players. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gauntlet">Gauntlet</link></style> supports between one and four players fighting monsters in dungeons and lets gameplay continue at long as at least one player in still in the game.

<style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> are groups of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and can be used in both <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. Unlike <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, they do not have to be formed from explicit gameplay goals. Instead, they are formed by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> based on the relations between the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. The use of <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> can further motivate the existence of <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>; the individual <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do not have all <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> necessary but together they do. These aspects explains why <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> are often not constructed from <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>: these do not provide abstract gameplay structures for supporting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> or having relations. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> shows that it is possible to create <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> through <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> by using <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Canned%20Text%20Responses">Canned Text Responses</link></style> to represent diegetic relations and norms during gameplay; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gauntlet">Gauntlet</link></style> also manages this by letting individual players have individual <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> and thereby not have the exact same gameplay goal. <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> can consist of purely <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> or of mixes of <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> (general <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> either have limited functionality or mobility, or do not work towards gameplay goals). While <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> can function through a single player controlling a single <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style>, letting that player switch his or her <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> allows for higher levels of control.

The number of members that Parties should or can have is a primary design choice for the pattern. Parties usually assume at least three members, so for example Torchlight - where players always have a pet companion but no other companions except temporary summoned monsters - does not qualify as using the pattern. Some games put a maximum number of members in the Parties, making member slots into Limited Resources. Early installments of the Fallout series let this number on the Player Character's charisma value while later installment had a fixed value of 2; the Left 4 Dead series always starts with four survivors at the beginning of each Level. While Multiplayer Games may have Parties consisting only of Player Characters, AI Players or Companions may be used in any type of game and can ensure that Parties have a certain number of members.

The issue of <style="CurrentLink">Party</style> size has additional complications for <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. This includes if one should allow <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> this can become especially sensitive. The reason for this is that <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> are personal and may have been developed over long periods of time, and there may be not diegetically plausible reasons why the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should absent or not <style="Link"><link="always-vulnerable">Always Vulnerable</link></style>. Related to this issue is if it should be possible for players to engage in <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> of members of their own <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>.

Although <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> are typically personal for each <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> in a game, in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> it is possible rationalize this to one common <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventory</link></style> if <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style> exist to show who is using what. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> is an example of a game using this solution.

The issue of <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> in multiplayer <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> can easily also become sensitive (up to causing <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayals</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> if possible) if not controlled by game mechanics, and for this reason games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> provides options for how <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> should be split.

Handling the details of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> is likely to require <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>. In games with <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>, it is also usual to have common <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> in additional to personal ones (e.g. representing the resources in the bases of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM series</link></style>) - for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> this may be a "Group Sheet" in addition to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style>.

Game designs can help <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> achieve <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> by letting them  place <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or on <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> so that the rest can see them. For both face-to-face and <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style> can help in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> by pointing out the various members <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>.

Companions in Parties can be natural pointed for Sidequests (these specific types of Sidequests are sometimes called Companion Quests). Examples of games that include them are found in the Fallout series and the Dragon Age series.

While <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can emerge spontaneously in <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>, it can also artificially be introduced into <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> as part of storylines to create more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> are social grouping of <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, which can be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> but do not have to be either of these since they do not have to have explicit goals. Although <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> make use of the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> pattern, the pattern can also be said to modulate <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> since it puts them in groups where they need to cooperate. Having a maximum number of members in <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> make them into a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. Games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> use this to force players to make <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> between which <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> to have in their <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style>. <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style> emerge from <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> where all <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are equally important and they are all controlled by a single player.

Regardless of it the <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> pattern is used in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, planning on how <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should work together can give rise to <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>, but also to <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> (the latter of these may end the existence of <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> or even the possibility of it may hinder them from forming). For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, having humans control other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> expands this to include <style="Link"><link="team-accomplishments">Team Accomplishments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-strategy-identification">Team Strategy Identification</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style>. In games where players can have <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> this translates to <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> typically also have <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and require <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> since consensus regarding plans of actions are needed for <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style>.

The <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> pattern can also have relations to the pattern <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, this can be due to actions being felt as <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> or other breaches of <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> while for any type of <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> consisting partly of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, behaving in ways deemed inappropriate by these may be the cause for them to leave the group (this can for example occur in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distribution%20of%20Rewards%20&%20Penalties">Player-Decided Distribution of Rewards & Penalties</link></style> occurs in many <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> that have <style="CurrentLink">Parties</style> and <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>, either by being self-organized by players before or during the division of the <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> or facilitated by rules chosen by the players. In both cases this needs <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-accomplishments">Team Accomplishments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-strategy-identification">Team Strategy Identification</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="always-vulnerable">Always Vulnerable</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>
